intro: Talauma salicifolia, commonly known as the willow-leaf talauma, is a flowering plant native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its lance-shaped leaves that resemble those of willow trees. The plant produces small, pale yellow flowers that are clustered in inflorescences, typically blooming in spring. Its bark is smooth and light gray, and it thrives in moist, shaded environments. Talauma salicifolia is often found in tropical and subtropical regions, growing along stream banks and in forest understories.
